editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

titleStmt.title: Ben Ionson, his Case is alterd. As it hath beene sundry times acted by the children of the Blacke-friers.
Case is alterd
Case is alterd.
Pleasant comedy called, The case is alterd.
titleStmt.author: Jonson, Ben, 1573?-1637.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed [by Nicholas Okes] for Bartholomew Sutton, dwelling in Paules Church-yard neere the great north doore of Paules Church,

note.p: Running title reads: A pleasant comedy, called The case is alterd.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: This is a very early release with many imperfections. Contact martinmueller@northwestern.edu for corrections and improvement. For more information about the project go to http://scalablereading.northwestern.edu

div.p: Ben: Jonson, his case is altered.
As it hath been sundry times acted by the children of Blackfriars.
At London printed for Bartholomew Sutton, dwelling in Paul's churchyard near the great North door of s. Paul's church. 1609.

div.head: A pleasant comedy called, the case is altered.
Scaena prima.
div.stage: Sound? after a flourish: Juniper a cobbler is discovered, sitting at work in his shop and singing.

sp.speaker: Juniper, onion, Antony Baladino.
sp.l: You woeful wights give ear a while,
And mark the tenor of my style,
Which shall such trembling hearts unfold
As seldom hath to fore been told.
Such chances rare and doleful news
Peace a god's name.
As may attempt your wits to muse.
A pox a god on you.
And cause such trickling tears to pass,
Except your hearts be flint or brass:
To hear the news which I shall tell,
That in Castilia once befell.
'Sblood, where didst thou learn to corrupt a man in the midst of a verse, ha?

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: God's lid man, service is ready to go up man, you must slip on your coat and come in, we lack waiters pitifully.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: A pitiful hearing, for now must I of a merry cobbler become mourning creature.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Well you'll come.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: Presto. Go to, a word to the wise, away, fly? vanish: lie there the weeds that I disdain to wear.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: God save you master juniper.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: What signior Antonio Balladino, welcome sweet ingle,

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: And how do you sir?

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Faith you see, put to my shifts here as poor retainers be oftentimes, sirrah Antony there's one of my fellows mightily enamoured of thee, and i'faith you slave, now you're come I'll bring you together, it's Peter onion, the groom of the hall, do you know him.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: No not yet, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: O he is one as right of thy humour as may be, a plain simple rascal, a true dunce, marry he hath been a notable villain in his time: he is in love, sirrah, with a wench, and I have preferred thee to him, thou shalt make him some pretty paradox or some allegory, how does my coat sit? well.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I very well.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Nam gods so, fellow juniper, come away.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: Art thou there mad slave, I come with a powder?. Sirrah fellow onion. I must have you peruse this gentleman well, and do him good offices of respect and kindness, as instance shall be given.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Nay good master onion what do you mean, I pray you sir you are too respective in good faith.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: I would not you should think so sir, for though I have no learning, yet I honour a scholar in any ground of the earth sir,
Shall I request your name sir?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: My name is Antonio Balladino.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Balladino? you are not pageant poet to the city of Milan sir ▪ are you.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I supply the place sir: when a worse cannot be had sir.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: I cry you mercy sir, I love you the better for that sir, by Jesu you must pardon me, I knew you not, but I'd pray to be better acquainted with you sir, I have seen of your works.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I am at your service good master onion, but concerning this maiden that you love sir? what is she,

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p:
O did my fellow juniper tell you? marry sir, she is
as one may say, but a poor man's child indeed, and for mine own part I am no gentleman born I must confess, but my mind to me a kingdom is truly.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Truly a very good saying.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: 'Tis somewhat stale, but that's no matter.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: O 'tis the better, such things ever are like bread, which the staler it is, the more wholesome.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: This is but a hungry comparison in my judgement.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Why, I'll tell you, m. onion, I do use as much stale stuff, though I say it myself, as any man does in that kind I am sure. Did you see the last pageant, I set forth?

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: No faith sir, but there goes a huge report on't.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Why, you shall be one of my Maecen-asses, I'll give you one of the books, oh you'll like it admirably.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Nay that's certain, I'll get my fellow juniper to read it.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Read it sir, I'll read it to you.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Tut then I shall not choose but like it.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Why look you sir, I write so plain, and keep that old decorum, that you must of necessity like it; marry you shall have some now (As for example, in plays) that will have every day new tricks, and write you nothing but humours: indeed this pleases the gentlemen: but the common sort they care not for't, they know not what to make on't, they look for good matter, they, and are not edified with such toys.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: You are in the right, I'll not give a halfpenny to see a thousand on 'em. I was at one the last term, but and ever I see a more roguish thing, I am a piece of cheese, and no onion, nothing but Kings and princes in it, the fool came not out a lot.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: True sir, they would have me make such plays, but as I tell hem, and they'll give me twenty pound a play, I'll not raise my vain.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: No, it were a vain thing, and you should sir.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Tut give me the penny, give me the penny, I care not for the gentlemen I, let me have a good ground, no matter for the pen the plot shall carry it.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p:
Indeed that's right, you are in print already for the
best plotter.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Ay, I might as well ha' been put in for a dumb show too.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: I marry sir, I mar'le you were not, stand aside sir a while:

div.stage: Enter an armd sewer: some half dozen in mourning coats following and pass by with service.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: How now friend, what are you there? be uncovered, would you speak with any man here?

sp.speaker: Valen,
sp.p: Ay, or else I must ha' returned you no answer.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Friend, you are somewhat too peremptory, let's crave your absence: nay never scorn it, I am a little your better in this place.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I do acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Do you acknowledge it? nay then you shall go forth, I'll teach you how shall acknowledge it another time; go to, void, I must have the hall purged, no setting up of a rest here, pack, begone.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I pray you sir is not your name onion?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Your friend as you may use him, and m. onion, say on.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: M. onion with a murrain, come come put off this lions hide, your ears have discovered you, why Peter! do not I know you Peter?

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: God's so, Valentine!

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: O can you take knowledge of me now sir?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Good lord, sirrah, how thou art altered with thy travel?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Nothing so much as thou art with thine office, but sirrah, onion is the count Ferneze at home?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: I bully, he is above; and the lord Paulo Ferneze, his son, and madam Aurelia, and madam Phaenixella, his daughters, but oh Valentine?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: How now man, how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Faith sad, heavy, as a man of my coat ought to be.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Why man, thou wert merry enough even now.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.l: True, but thou knowest
All creatures here sojourning, upon this wretched earth,
Sometimes have a fit of mourning, as well as a fit of mirth.
O Valentine, mine old lady is dead, man.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Dead!

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: i'faith.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: When died she?

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Marry, tomorrow shall be three months, she was seen going to heaven they say, about some five weeks ago! how now? trickling tears, ha?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Faith thou hast made me weep with this news.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Faith thou hast made me weep with this news.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Why I have done but the part of an onion, you must pardon me.

div.head: Scene. 2.
div.stage: Enter the sewer, pass by with service again, the serving-men take knowledge of Valentine as they go. Juniper salutes him.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: What Valentine? fellow onion, take my dish I prithee you rogue sirrah, tell me, how thou dost, sweet ingle.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Faith, juniper, the better to see thee thus frolic.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Nay, slid I am no changeling, I am juniper still. Exit Oni.I keep the pristmate ha, you mad hieroglyphic, when shall we swagger.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Hieroglyphic, what meanest thou by that.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Mean? God's so, is't not a good word man? what? stand upon meaning with your friends. Puh, abscond.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Why, but stay, stay, how long has this sprightly humour haunted thee?

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Foe humour, a foolish natural gift we have in the equinoctial.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Natural, slid it may be supernatural, this?

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Valentine, I prithee ruminate thyself welcome. What fortuna de la guerra.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: O how pitifully are these words forced.
As though they were pumped out on's belly.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Sirrah ingle, I think thou hast seen all the strange countries in Christendom since thou wentest?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I have seen some juniper.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: You have seen Constantinople?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Ay, that I have.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: And Jerusalem, and the Indies, and Goodwin sands, and the tower of Babylon, and Venice and all.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I all; 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 and he have a nimble tongue, if he practise to vault thus from one side of the world to another.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: O it's a most heavenly thing to travel, and see countries, especially at sea, and a man had a patent not to be sick.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: O sea sick lest, and full of the scurvy.

div.head: Scene 3.
div.stage: Enter Juniper, Antonio, Sebastian, Martino, Vincentio, Balthasar and Christophero.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p: Valentine? welcome i'faith how dost sirrah?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: How do you good Valentine.

sp.speaker: Vincen.
sp.p: Troth, Valentine, I am glad to see you.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: Welcome sweet rogue.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Before God he never looked better in his life.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: And how is't man? what, alla coragio.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Never better gentlemen i'faith.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: S'will here comes the steward.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Why how now fellows all here? and nobody to weight above now they are ready to rise? look up one or two signior Francesco Colomia's man how does your good master.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: In health sir he will be here anon.

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.p: Is he come home, then?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Ay sir he is not passed six miles hence, he sent me before to learn if count Ferneze were here and return him word.

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.p: Yes, my lord is here; and you may tell your master he shall come very happily to take his leave of lord Paulo Ferneze: who is now instantly to depart with other noble gentlemen, upon special service.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I will tell him sir.

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.p: I pray you do, fellows make him drink.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Sirs, what service is't they are employed in?

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Why against the French they mean to have a fling at Milan again they say.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Who leads our forces, can you tell?

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Marry that does signior Maximilian? he is above, now.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Who, Maximilian of Vicenza?

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.p: I he? do you know him?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Know him? O yes he's an excellent brave soldier.

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.p: I so they say, but one of the most vain glorious men in Europe.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: He is indeed, marry exceeding valiant.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: And that is rare.

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.p: What.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Why to see a vainglorious man valiant.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Well he is so I assure you.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: What no further yet, come on you precious rascal, sir Valentine, I'll give you a health i'faith, for the heavens you mad capriccio, hold hook and line.

div.head: Scene 4.
div.stage: Enter lord Paulo Ferneze, his boy following him.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Sirrah go up to signior Angelio,
And pray him (If he can) devise some means,
To leave my father, and come speak with me.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I will my lord.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Well heaven, be auspicious in the event;
For I do this against my genius,
And yet my thoughts cannot propose a reason.
Why I should fear, or faint thus in my hopes,
Of one so much endeared to my love.
Some spark it is, kindled within the soul:
Whose light yet breaks not to the outward sense,
That propagates this timorous suspect;
His actions never carried any face
Of change, or weakness: then I injury him?
In being thus cold conceited of his faith,
Oh here he comes.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: How now sweet lord, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Good faith his presence makes me half ashamed.
Of my strayed thoughts. Boy. Bestow yourself.
Where is my father, signior Angelio.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Marry in the gallery, where your lordship left him.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: That's well. Then Angelio I will be brief.
Since time forbids the use of circumstance,
How well you are received in my affection,
Let it appear by this one instance, only
That now I will deliver to your trust,
The dearest secrets, treasured in my bosom,
Dear Angelio. You are not every man,
But one, whom my election hath designed,
As the true proper object of my soul:
I urge not this t'insinuate my desert,
Or supple your tried temper, with soft phrases;
True friendship loathes such oily compliment:
But from th'abundance of that love, that flows
Through all my spirits, is my speech enforced.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Before your lordship do proceed too far,
Let me be bold to intimate thus much;
That whatsoe'er your wisdom hath t'expose,
Be it the weightiest and most rich affair,
That ever was included in your breast,
My faith shall poise it, if not —

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: O no more,
Those words have rapt me with their sweet effects,
So freely breathed, and so responsible,
To that which I endeavoured to extract,
Arguing a happy mixture of our souls.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Why were there no such sympathy sweet lord?
Yet the impressure of those ample favours,
I have derived from your unmatched spirit,
Would bind my faith to all observances.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: How! favours Angelo, o speak not of them,
They are mere paintings, and import no merit,
Looks my love well? thereon my hopes are placed:
Faith, that is bought with favours, cannot last.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You are sought for all about the house, within,
The count your father calls for you.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: God, what cross events do meet my purposes?
Now will he violently fret and grieve
That I am absent. Boy, say I come presently:
Sweet Angelo, I cannot now insist
Upon particulars, I must serve the time
The main of all this is, I am in love.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Why starts your lordship?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I thought I heard my father coming hither ward, list, ha?

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: I hear not any thing, it was but your imagination sure.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: No, I assure your lordship.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I would work safely.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Why, has he no knowledge of it then?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: O no, no creature yet partakes it but yourself
In a third person, and believe me friend,
The world contains not now another spirit,
To whom I would reveal it. Hark, hark,

div.stage: Servants. Signior Paulo. Lord Ferneze. within.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: A pox upon those brazen throated slaves,
What are they mad, trow?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Alas, blame not them,
Their services are (Clock-like) to beset,
Backward and forward, at their lords command,
You know my father's wayward, and his humour
Must not receive a check, for then all objects,
Feed both his grief and his impatience,
And those affections in him, are like powder,
Apt to inflame with every little spark,
And blow up reason, therefore Angelo, peace.

div.stage:
Within. Count.
Why this is rare, is he not in the garden?Crist.
I know not my lord.Count.
See, call him?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: He is coming this way, let's withdraw a little.

div.stage: Within. Seruants. Signior Paulo, lord Ferneze, lord Paulo.

div.head: Scene 5.
div.stage: Enter count Ferneze, Maximilian, Aurelia, Phoenixella, Sebast. Balthasar.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Where should he be, trow? did you look in the armoury?

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: No my lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, why there? O who would keep such drones? Exeunt Sebast. and Baltha.how now, ha ye found him?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: No my lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: No my lord, I shall have shortly all my family
Speak naught, but no my lord, where is Christophero,
Look how he stands, you sleep y knave,
What is he not in the garden?

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.p: No my good lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Your good lord, o how this smells of fennel. Enter Sebast Baltha.you have been in the garden it appears, well, well.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: We cannot find him my lord.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: He is not in the armoury.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: He is not, he is nowhere , is he?

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: Count Ferneze.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Signior.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: Preserve your patience honourable count.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Patience? A saint would lose his patience to be crossed,
As I am with a sort of motley brains,
See see, how like a nest of rooks they stand,
Gaping on one another! now diligence, what news bring you?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: An't please your honour.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Tut, tut, leave pleasing of my honour diligence, you double with we, come.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: How: does he find fault with please his honour. 'swounds it has begun a serving man's speech, ever since I belonged to the blue order: I know not how it may show, now I am in black, but —

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What's that, you mutter sir? will you proceed?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: An't like your good lordship.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yet more; gods precious.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: What, do not this like him neither?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What say you sir knave?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Marry I say your lordship were best to set me to school again, to learn how to deliver a message.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What do you take exceptions at me then.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Exception? I take no exceptions, but by gods so your humours —

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Go to you are a rascal, hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Your lordship's poor servant, I.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Tempt not my patience.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Why I hope I am no spirit, am I?

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: My lord, command your steward to correct the slave.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Correct him, 'sblood come you and correct him and you have a mind to it, correct him, that's a good jest i'faith, the steward and you both, come and correct him.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Nay see, away with him, pull his cloth over his ears.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Cloth? tell me of your cloth, here's your cloth, nay and I mourn a minute longer, I am the rottenest onion that ever spoke with a tongue.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: What call your hinds count Ferneze?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: His name is onion signior,

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: I thought him some such saucy companion.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Signior Maximillian.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: Sweet lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Let me entreat you, you would not regard
Any contempt flowing from such a spirit,
So rude, so barbarous.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: Most noble count under your favour —

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: Why I'll tell you signior,
He'll bandy with me word for word, nay more,
Put me to silence, strike me perfect dumb;
And so amaze me, that oftentimes I know not,
Whether to check or cherish his presumption:
Therefore good signior.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: Sweet lord satisfy yourself, I am not now to learn how to manage my affections, I have observed, and know the difference between a base wretch and a true man, I can distinguish them, the property of the wretch is, he would hurt and cannot, of the man, he can hurt, and will not.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: Go to, my merry daughter, o these looks,
Agree well with your habit, do they not?

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: Tut, let me alone. By your favour, this is the gentleman I think, sir you appear to be an honourable gentleman, I understand, and could wish (For mine own part) that things were conden't otherwise than they are: but (The world knows) a foolish fellow, somewhat proclive, and hasty, he did it in a prejudicate humour; marry now upon better computation, he wanes; he melts; his poor eyes are in a cold sweat. Right noble signior, you can have but compunction, I love the man, tender your compassion.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: Doth any man here understand this fellow?

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: O God sir, I may say frustra to the comprehension of your intellection.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.l: Before the lord, he speaks all riddle, I think.
I must have a comment ere I can conceive him.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Why he sues to have his fellow onion pardoned,
And you must grant it signior.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: O with all my soul my lord, is that his motion?

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: Ay sir, and we shall retort these kind favours with all alacrity of spirit, we can sir, as may be most expedient, as well for the quality as the cause, till when in spite of this compliment: I rest a poor cobbler, servant to my honourable lord here, your friend and juniper.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: How juniper?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I signior.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: He is a sweet youth, his tongue has a happy turn when he sleeps.

div.stage: Enter Paulo Ferneze, Francisco, Colomea, Angelo, Valentine.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I for then it rests, oh sir your welcome,
Why God be thanked you are found at last.
Signior Coloma truly you are welcome,
I am glad to see you sir so well returned.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I gladly thank your honour, yet indeed
I am sorry for such cause of heaviness,
As hath possessed your lordship in my absence.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O Francisco you knew her what she was!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: She was a wise and honourable lady.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I was she not! well weep not she is gone,
Passions dulled eye can make two grieves of one,
Whom death mark out, virtue, nor blood can save,
Princes, as beggars, all must feed the grave.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Are your horse ready lord Paulo,

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I signior the stay for us at the gate.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Well 'tis good. Ladies I will take my leave of you,
Be your fortunes as yourselves? fair. Come let us to horse,
Count Ferneze I bear a spirit full of thanks for all your honourable courtesies.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir I could wish the number and value of them more in respect of your deservings. But signior Maximillian. I pay you a word in private.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: i'faith brother you are fitted for a general yonder, beshrew my heart (If I had Fortunatus' hat here) and I would not wish myself a man and go with you, only t'enjoy his presence.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Why do you love him so well sister.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: No by my troth, but I have such an odd pretty apprehension of his humour methinks : that I am e'en tickled with the conceit of it.
O he is a fine man.

sp.speaker: Ang
sp.p: And methinks another may be as fine as he.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: O Angelio, do you think I do urge any comparison against you? no, I am not so ill bred, as to be a depraver of your worthiness: believe me, if I had not some hope of your abiding with us, I should never desire to go out of black whilst I lived: but learn to speak i'the nose, and turn Puritan presently.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I thank you lady: I know you can flout.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Come do you take it so? I'faith you wrong me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Ay, but madam,
Thus to disclaim in all the effects of pleasure,
May make your sadness seem to much affected,
And then the proper grace of it is lost.

sp.speaker: Phoenix
sp.l: Indeed sir, if I did put on this sadness
Only abroad, and in society,
And were in private merry; and quick humoured;
Then might it seem affected and abhorred:
But as my looks appear, such is my spirit,
Drowned up with confluence of grief, and melancholy,
That like to rivers run through all my veins,
Quenching the pride and fervour of my blood.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: My honourable lord? no more.
There is the honour of my blood engaged,
For your son's safety.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Signior, blame me not,
For tending his security so much,
He is mine only son, and that word only,
Hath with his strong, and reprecussive sound,
Stroke my heart cold, and given it a deep wound.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Why but stay, I beseech you, had your lordship ever any more sons than this.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Why have not you known it Maximilian?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Let my sword fail me then.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I had one other younger born than this,
By twice so many hours as would fill
The circle of a year, his name Camillo,
Whom in that black, and fearful night I lost,
('tis now a nineteen years ago at least,
And yet the memory of it fits as fresh
Within my brain as 'twere but yesterday)
It was that night wherein the great Chamont,
The general for France surprised Vicenza,
Methinks the horror of that clamorous shout
His soldiers gave when they attained the wall,
Yet tingles in mine ear, methinks I see
With what amazed looks, distracted thoughts,
And minds confused, we, that were citizens,
Confronted one another: every street
Was filled with bitter self tormenting cries,
And happy was that foot, that first could press,
The flowery champagne, bordering on Verona
Here I (Employed about my dear wife's safety)
Whose soul is now in peace) lost my Camillo.
Who sure was murdered by the barbarous soldiers,
Or else I should have heard — my heart is great.
Sorrow is faint? and passion makes me sweat.

sp.speaker: Max
sp.p: Grieve not sweet count: comfort your spirits, you have a son a noble gentleman, he stands in the face of honour: for his safety let that be no question. I am master of my fortune, and he shall share with me. Farewell my honourable lord. Ladies once more adieu, for yourself madam you are a most rare creature, I tell you so, be not proud of it, I love you: come lord Paulo to horse.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Adieu good signior Francesco: farewell sister.

div.stage: Sound a tucket, and as they pass every one severally depart, Maximilian, Paulo Ferneze and Angelo remain

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: How shall we rid him hence.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Why well enough? sweet signior Maximilian.
I have some small occasion to stay:
If it may please you but take horse afore
I'll over take you, ere your troops be ranged.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Your motion hath taste well: lord Ferneze I go

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Now if my love fair Rachel, were so happy,
But to look forth. See fortune doth me grace.
Before I can demand? how now love.
Where is your father?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Gone abroad my lord:

sp.speaker: Pau:
sp.p: That's well,

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: I but I fear he'll presently return,
Are you now going my most honoured lord?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I my sweet Rachel.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Before God, she is a sweet wench.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Rachel I hope I shall not need to urge,
The sacred purity of our effects,
As if it hung in trial or suspense:
Since in our hearts, and by our mutual vows,
It is confirmed and sealed in sight of heaven.
Nay do not weep, why start you? fear not, love.
Your father cannot be returned so soon,
I prithee do not look so heavily
Thou shalt want nothing

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: No is your presence nothing,
I shall want that, and wanting that, want all
For that is all to me.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Content thee sweet
I have made choice here of a constant friend
This gentleman? one, whose zealous love
I do repose more, than on all the world,
Thy beauteous self excepted: and to him,
Have I committed my dear care of thee,
As to my genius, or my other soul.
Receive high gentle love and what defects,
My absence proves, his presence shall supply.
The time is envious of our longer stay.
Farewell dear Rachel.

sp.speaker: Rach:
sp.l: Most dear lord, adieu,
Heaven and honour crown your deeds, and you,

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Faith tell me Angelio how dost thou like her?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Troth well my lord, but shall I speak my mind.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I prithee do.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: She is derived too meanly to be wife
To such a noble person, in my judgement.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Nay then thy judgement is to meene, I see:
Didst thou ne'er read in difference of good
'Tis more to shine in virtue then in blood.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Come you are so sententious my lord.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Here comes her father. How dost thou good Jaques?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: God save thee Jaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: What should this mean? Rachel open the door.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: 'Sblood how the poor slave looks, as though
He had been haunted by the spirit Lar,
Or seen the ghost of some great satrap.
In an unsavoury sheet.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: I muse he spoke no, belike he was amazed
Coming so suddenly and unprepared? Well let's go:

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.l: So now enough my heart, beat now no more;
At least for this affright, what 'a could sweat,
Flowed on my brows, and over all my bosom!
Had I not reason? to behold my door
Beset with unthrifts, and myself abroad?
Why Jaques? was their nothing in the house
Worth a continual eye, a vigilant thought,
Whose head should never nod, nor eyes once wink?
Look on my coat; my thoughts; worn quite thread bare,
That time could never cover with a nap,
And by it learn, never with naps of sleep,
To smother your conceits of that you keep.
But yet, I marvel, why these gallant youth's
Spoke Me so fair, and I esteemed a beggar?
The end of flattery, is gain, or lechery:
If they seek gain of me, they think me rich,
But that they do not: for their other object:
'Tis in my handsome daughter, if it be.
And by your leave, her handsomeness may tell them
My beggary counterfeits, and, that her neatness,
Flows from some store of wealth, that breaks my coffers,
With this same engine, love to mine own breed.
But this is answered: beggars will keep fine,
Their daughters, being fair, though themselves pine.
Well then, it is for her, ay, 'tis sure for her,
And I make her so brisk for some of them,
That I might live alone once with my gold.
O 'tis a sweet companion! kind and true,
A man may trust it when his father cheats him;
Brother, or friend, or wife, o wondrous pelf,
"That which makes all men false, is true itself.
But now this maid, is but supposed my daughter:
For I being steward to a lord of France,
Of great estate, and wealth, called lord Chamount,
He gone into the wars, I stole his treasure,
(But hear not, any thing) I stole his treasure,
And this his daughter, being but two years old,
Because it loved me so, that it would leave
The nurse herself, to come into mine arms,
And had I left it, it would sure have died.
Now herein I was kind, and had a conscience;
And since her lady mother that did die
In childbed of her, loved me passing well,
It may be nature fashioned this affection,
Both in the child and her: but he's ill bred,
That ransacks tombs, and doth deface the dead.
I'll therefore say no more: suppose the rest,
Here have I changed my form, my name and hers.
And live obscurely, to enjoy more safe
My dearest treasure. But I must abroad, Rachel.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: What is your pleasure sir?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Rachel I must abroad.
Lock thyself in, but yet take out the key,
That whosoever peeps in at the keyhole,
May yet imagine there is none at home.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: But hark thee Rachel: say a thief should come,
And miss the key, he would resolve indeed
None were at home, and so break in the rather:
Open the door Rachel, set it open daughter;
But sit in it thyself: and talk aloud,
As if there were some more in house with thee:
Put out the fire, kill the chimney's heart,
That it may breathe no more than a dead man,
The more we spare my child, the more we gain.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: What says my fellow onion? come on.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: All of a house sir, but no fellows, you are my lords steward, but I pray you what think you of love, sir?

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Of love onion? Why it's a very honourable humour.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Nay if it be but worshipful I care not.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: Go to, it's honourable, check not at the conceit of the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.l: But in truth sir, you shall do well to think well of love:
For it thinks well of you, in me, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Gramercy fellow onion: I do think well, thou art in love, art thou?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Partly sir, but I am ashamed to say wholly.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Well, I will further it in thee to any honest woman, or maiden, the best I can.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.l: Why now you come near him sir, he doth veil,
He doth remunerate, he doth chaw the cud in the kindness
Of an honest imperfection to your worship.

sp.speaker: Chris
sp.p: But who is it thou lovest fellow onion?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Marry a poor man's daughter, but none of the honestest, I hope.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Why, wouldst thou not have her honest?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: O no, for then I am sure she would not have me. 'tis Rachel de Pry.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Why, she hath the name of a very virtuous maiden.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: So she is sir, but the fellow talks in quiddits, he.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: What wouldst thou have me do in the matter?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Do nothing sir, I pray you, but speak for me.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: In what manner?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: My fellow juniper can tell you sir.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: Why as thus sir. Your worship may commend him for a fellow fit for consanguinity, and that he shaketh with desire of procreation, or so.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: That were not so good, methinks .

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: No sir, why so sir? what if you should say to her, corroborate thyself sweet soul, let me distinguish thy paps with my fingers, divine Mumps, pretty Pastorella? lookest thou so sweet and bounteous? comfort my friend here.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Well I perceive you wish, I should say something may do him grace, and further his desires, and that be sure I will.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: I thank you sir, God save your life, I pray God sir.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: Your worship is too good to live long: you'll contaminate me no service.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Command thou wouldst say, no good juniper.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: Health and wealth sir.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: This wench will solicit for myself,
Making my lord and master privy to it;
And if he second me with his consent,
I will proceed, as having long ere this,
Though her a worthy choice to make my wife.

sp.speaker: Avre.
sp.l: Room for a case of matrons coloured black,
How motherly my mother's death hath made us?
I would I had some girls now to bring up;
Oh I could make a wench so virtuous,
She should say grace to every bit of meat,
And gape no wider than a wafer's thickness:
And she should make French curtsies, so most low,
That every touch should turn her over backward.

sp.speaker: Phoeni.
sp.l: Sister, these words become not your attire,
Nor your estate: our virtuous mother's death
Should print more deep effects of sorrow in us,
Then may be worn out in so little time.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Sister, faith you take too much tobacco,
It makes you black within, as you're without.
What true-stich sister? both your sides alike?
Be of a slighter work: for of my word,
You shall be sold as dear or rather dearer?
Will you be bound to customs and to rites?
Shed profitable tears, weep for advantage;
Or else, do all things, as you are inclined.
Hate when your stomach serves (Saith the physician)
Not at eleven and six. So if your humour
Be now affected with this heaviness.
Give me the reins and spare not, as I do,
In this my pleasurable appetite,
It is precisianism to alter that
With austere judgement, that is given by nature.
I wept you saw too, when my mother died:
For then I found it easier to do so,
And fitter with my mood, than not to weep.
But now 'tis otherwise, another time
Perhaps I shall have such deep thoughts of her,
That I shall weep a fresh, some twelvemonth hence,
And I will weep, if I be so disposed,
And put on black, as grimly then, as now;
Let the mind go still with the body's stature,
Judgement is fit for judges, give me nature.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: See signior Angelo here are the ladies,
Go you and comfort one, I'll to the other.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Therefore I come sir, I'll to the eldest.
God save you ladies, these sad moods of yours,
That make you choose these solitary walks,
Are hurtful for your beauties.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.p: If we had them.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Come, that condition might be for your hearts,
When you protest faith, since we cannot see them.
But this same heart of beauty, your sweet face
Is in mine eye still.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.p: O you cut my heart with your sharp eye.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Nay lady that's not so, your heart's too hard.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.p: My beauty's heart?

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: O no.
I mean that regent of affection, madam,
That tramples on all love with such contempt in this fair breast.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: No more, your drift is savoured,
I had rather seem hard hearted

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Then hard favoured,
Is that your meaning, lady?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Go too sir.
Your wits are fresh I know, they need no spur,

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: And therefore you will ride them.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Say I do.
They will not tire I hope?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: No not with you, hark you sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Tis much pity madam.
You should have any reason to retain
This sign of grief, much less the thing designed.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Griefs are more fit for ladies then their pleasures.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: That is for such as follow naught but pleasures.
But you that temper them so well with virtues,
Using your griefs so it would prove them pleasures.
And you would seem in cause of griefs and pleasures equally pleasant.

sp.speaker: Phoe
sp.l: Sir so I do now.
It is the excess of either that I strive
So much to shun in all my proved endeavours,
Although perhaps unto a general eye,
I may appear most wedded to my griefs,
Yet doth my mind forsake no taste of pleasure,
I mean that happy pleasure of the soul,
Divine and sacred contemplation
Of that eternal, and most glorious bliss.
Proposed as the crown unto our souls.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I will be silent, yet that I may serve
But as a decade in the art of memory
To put you still in mind of your own virtues
When your too serious thoughts make you too sad)
Accept me for your servant honored lady.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Those ceremonies are too common signior Francis,
For your uncommon gravity, and judgement,
And fits them only, that are naught but ceremony.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Come, I will not sue, stally to be your servant,
But a new term, will you be my refuge?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Your refuge, why sir.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: That I might fly to you, when all else fail me.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And you be good at flying, be my plover.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Nay take away the P.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Tut, than you cannot fly.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I'll warrant you. I'll borrow Cupid's wings.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Mass then I fear me you'll do strange things:
I pray you blame me not, if I suspect you,
Your own confession simply doth detect you,
Nay and you be so great in Cupid's books,
'Twill make me jealous. you can with your looks
(I warrant you) inflame a woman's heart,
And at your pleasure take love's golden dart,
And wound the breast of any virtuous maid.
Would I were hence: good faith I am afraid,
You can constrain one ere they be aware,
To run mad for your love?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: O this is rate.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Close with my daughter's gentlemen? well done,
'Tis like yourselves: nay lusty Angelo,
Let not my presence make you balk your sport,
I will not break a minute of discourse
Twixt you and one of your fair mistresses.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: One of my mistresses? why thinks your lordship I have so many

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Many? no Angelo.
I do not think thou'st many, some fourteen
I hear thou hast, even of our worthiest dames,
Of any note, in Milan:

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Nay good my lord fourteen: it is not so.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: By'th the mass that is't, here are their names to show
Fourteen, or fifteen t'one. Good Angelo.
You need not be ashamed of any of them,
They are gallants all.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: 'Sblood you are such a lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Nay stay sweet Angelo, I am disposed
A little to be pleasant passed my custom,
He's gone? he's gone, I have disgraced him shrewdly,
Daughters take heed of him, he's a wild youth,
Look what he says to you believe him not,
He will swear love to every one he sees.
Francisco, give them council, good Francisco,
I dare trust thee with both, but him with neither.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Your lordship yet may trust both them with him.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Well go your ways away; how now Christopher,
What news with you?

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: I have an humble suit to your good lordship.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: A suit Christopher? what suit I prithee?

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.l: I would crave pardon at your lordship's hands,
If it seem vain or simple in your sight.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I'll pardon all simplicity, Christopher,
What is thy suit?

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.l: Perhaps being now so old a bachelor,
I shall seem half unwise, to bend myself
In strict affection to a poor young maid.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: What? is it touching love Christopher?
Art thou disposed to marry, why 'tis well.

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.l: Ay, but your lordship may imagine now
That I being steward of your honour's house.
If I be married once, will more regard
The maintenance of my wife and of my charge,
Than the due discharge of my place and office.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, no, Christopher, I know thee honest.

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.p: Good faith my lord, your honour may suspect it ▪ but —

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Then I should wrong thee, thou hast ever been
Honest and true, and will be still I know.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: I but this marriage alters many men:
And you may fear, it will do me my lord,
But ere it do so? I will undergo
Ten thousand several deaths.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I know it man.
Who wouldst thou have I prithee?

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: Rachel de prie,
If your good lordship, grant me your consent.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Rachel de prie? what the poor beggar's daughter?
She's a right handsome maid, how poor soever,
And thou hast my consent, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: I humbly thank your honour. I'll now ask her father.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Do so Christofero thou shalt do well.
'Tis strange (She being so poor) he should affect her,
But this is more strange that myself should love her.
I spied her, lately, at her father's door,
And if I did not see in her sweet face
Gentry and nobleness, ne'er trust me more:
But this persuasion, fancy wrought in me,
That fancy being created with her looks,
For where love is he think his basest object
Gentle and noble: I am far in love,
And shall be forced to wrong my honest steward,
For I must sue, and seek her for myself;
How much my duty to my late dead wife,
And my own dear renown soe'er it sways,
He to her father straight. Love hates delays.

div.head: Scene 8.
div.stage: Enter onion, Juniper, Valentine, Sebastian, Balthasar, Martino.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Come on i'faith, let's to some exercise or other my hearts: fetch the hilts fellow juniper, wilt thou play:

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: I cannot resolve you? 'tis as I am fitted with the ingenuity, quantity, or quality of the cudgel.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: How dost thou bastinado the poor cudgel with terms?

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: O ingle, I have the phrases man, and the anagrams and the epitaphs, fitting the mystery of the noble science.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: I'll be hanged and he were not misbegotten of some fencer.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Sirrah Valentine, you can resolve me now, have they their masters of defence in other countries as we have here in Italy?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: O lord, ay, especially they in Utopia, there they perform their prizes and challenges, with as great ceremony as the Italian or any nation else.

sp.speaker: Balt
sp.p: Indeed? how is the manner of it (For gods love) good Valentine?

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Ingle? I prithee make recourse unto us, we are thy friends and familiars: sweet ingle.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Why thus sir.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: God a mercy good Valentine, nay go on.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Silentium bonus socius onionus, good fellow Onion be not so ingenious, and turbulent: so fir? and how? how sweet ingle?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Marry, first they are brought to the public theater:

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: What? ha? they theater there

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Theatres? I and plays to: both tragedy and comedy and set forth with as much state as can be imagined?

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: By gods so; a man is nobody, till he has travelled.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: And how are their plays? as ours are? extemporal?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: O no? all premeditated things, and some of them very good i'faith, my master used to visit them often when he was there.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: Why how are they in a place where any man may see them?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Ay, in the common theatres, I tell you. But the sport is at a new play to observe the sway and variety of opinion that passeth it. A man shall have such a confused mixture of judgement, poured out in the throng there, as ridiculous, as laughter itself: one says he likes not the writing, another likes not the plot, another not the playing. And sometimes a fellow that comes not there passed once in five year at a parliament time or so, will be as deep mired in censuring as the best, and swear by god's foot he would never stir his foot to see a hundred such as that is.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: I must travel to see these things, I shall ne'er think well of myself else.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: Fellow onion, I'll bear thy charges and thou wilt but pilgrimize it along with me, to the land of Utopia.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Why but methinks such rooks as these should be ashamed to judge.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Not a whit? the rankest stinkard of them all, will take upon him as peremptory, as if he had writ himself in artibus magister.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: And do they stand to a popular censure for any thing they present.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I ever, ever, and the people generally are very acceptive and apt to applaud any meritable work, but there are two sorts of persons that most commonly are infectious to a whole auditory.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: What be they?

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: I come let's know them.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: It were good they were noted.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p:
Marry? one is the rude barbarous crew, a people that have no brains, and yet grounded judgements, these will hiss
any thing that mounts above their grounded capacities. But the other are worth the observation, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: What be they? what be they?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Faith a few capricious gallants.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: Capricious? stay, that word's for me.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: And they have taken such a habit of dislike in all things, that they will approve nothing, be it never so conceited or elaborate, but sit dispersed, making faces, and spitting, wagging their upright ears and cry filthy, filthy. Simply uttering their own condition, and using their wried countenances in stead of a vice, to turn the good aspects of all that shall sit near them, from what they behold.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.l: O that's well said, lay them down, come sirs.
Who plays, fellow juniper, Sebastian, Balthasar:
Somebody take them up, come.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: Ingle Valentine?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Not I sir, I profess it not.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: Sebastian.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Balthasar.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: Who? I?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Come, but one bout, I'll give hem thee, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: Why, here's Martino.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Foe he, alas he cannot play a whit, man.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: That's all one: no more could you in stata quo prius, Martino, play with him, every man has his beginning and conduction.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Will you not hurt me fellow onion?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Hurt thee, no? and I do, put me among potherbs, and chop me to pieces, come on?

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: By your favour sweet bullies give them room, back, so, Martino, do not look so thin upon the matter.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Ha, well played, fall over to my leg now? so, to your guard again, excellent, to my head now, make home your blow: spare not me, make it home, good, good a gain.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Why how now Peter?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: God's so, onion has caught a bruise.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: Couragio? be not capricious? what?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Capricious? not I, I scorn to be capricious for a scratch, Martino must have another bout, come.

sp.speaker: Val. Seb. Balth.
sp.p: No, no, play no more, play no more.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Foe, 'tis nothing a Philip, a device, fellow juniper prithee get me a plantain, I had rather play with one that had skill by half.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: By my troth, fellow onion, 'twas against my will.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.l: Nay that's not so, 'twas against my head,
But come, we'll ha' one bout more.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: Not a bout, not a stroke.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: No more, no more.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: Why I'll give you demonstration, how it came, thou openest the dagger to falsify over with the back sword frick, and he interrupted, before he could fall to the close.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: No, no, I know best how it was better than any man here, I felt his play presently: for look you, I gathered upon him thus, thus do you see? for the double lock, and took it single on the head.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: He says very true, he took it single on the head.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Come let's go.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Here fellow onion, here's a cobweb.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: How? A cobweb Martino, I will have another bout with you? 'swounds do you first break my head, and then give me a plaster in scorn? come to it, I will have a bout.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: God's my witness.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Tut! your witness cannot serve.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: 'Sblood? why what, thou art not lunatic, art thou? and thou beest avoid Mephistopheles. Say the sign should be in Aries now: as it may be for all us, where were your life? Answer me that?

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: He says well, onion.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I indeed does he.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p:
Come, come, you are a foolish naturalist, go, get a white a of an egg, and a little flax, and close the breach of the
head, it is the most conducible thing that can be. Martino, do not insinuate upon your good fortune, but play an honest part and bear away the bucklers.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: My young and simple friend, Paulo Ferneze,
Bound me with mighty solemn conjurations,
To be true to him, in his love, to Rachel,
And to solicit his remembrance still,
In his enforced absence, much, i'faith.
True to my friend in cases of affection?
In women's cases? what a jest it is?
How silly he is, that imagines it!
He is an ass that will keep promise strictly
In any thing that checks his private pleasure;
Chiefly in love. 'sblood am not I a man?
Have I not eyes that are as free to look?
And blood to be inflamed as well as his?
And when it is so, shall I not pursue
Mine own love's longings, but prefer my friends?
I 'tis a good fool, do so, hang me then,
Because I swore, alas, who does not know,
That lovers perjuries are ridiculous?
Have at thee Rachel: I'll go court her sure:
For now I know her father is abroad.
'Sblood see, he is here, o what damned luck is this?
This labour's lost, I must by no means see him.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Mischief and hell, what is this man a spirit,
Haunts he my house's ghost? still at my door?
He has been at my door, he has been in,
In my dear door: pray God my gold be safe.
God's pity, here's another. Rachel, ho Rachel.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: God save you honest father.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Rachel, God's light, come to me, Rachel, Rachel!

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: Now in god's name what ails he? this is strange!
He loves his daughter so, I'll lay my life,
That he's afraid, having been now abroad,
I come to seek her love unlawfully.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: 'Tis safe, 'tis safe, they have not robbed my treasure.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Let it not seem offensive to you sir.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Sir, god's my life, sir, sir, call me sir.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Good father hear me.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: You are most welcome sir,
I meant almost; and would your worship speak?
Would you abase yourself to speak to me?

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: 'Tis no abasing father: my intent
Is to do further honour to you sir
Then only speak: which is to be your son.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: My gold is in his nostrils, he has smelled it,
Break breast, break heart, fall on the earth my entrails,
With this same bursting admiration!
He knows my gold, he knows of all my treasure,
How do you know sir? whereby do you guess?

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: At what sir? what is't you mean?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: I ask, an't please your gentle worship, how you know?
I mean, how I should make your worship know
That I have nothing —
To give with my poor daughter? I have nothing:
The very air, bounteous to every man,
Is scant to me, sir.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: I do think good father, you are but poor,

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: He thinks so, hark, but think so:
He thinks not so, he knows of all my treasure.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: Poor man he is so overjoyed to hear
His daughter may be passed his hopes bestowed,
That betwixt fear and hope (If I mean simply)
He is thus passionate.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Yet all is safe within, is none without?
Nobody break my walls?

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: What say you father, shall I have your daughter?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I have no dowry to bestow upon her.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: I do expect none, father.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: That is well,
Than I beseech your worship make no question
Of that you wish, 'tis too much favour to me.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: I'll leave him now to give his passion's breath,
Which being settled, I will fetch his daughter:
I shall but move too much, to speak now to him.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: So, he's gone, would all were dead and gone,
That I might live with my dear gold alone.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Here is the poor old man.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Out of my soul another, comes he hither?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Be not dismayed old man, I come to cheer you.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: To me by heaven,
Turn ribs to brass, turn voice into a trumpet,
To rattle out the battles of my thoughts,
One comes to hold me talk, while th'other robs me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: He has forgotten me sure: what should this mean?
He fears authority, and my want of wife
Will take his daughter from him to defame her:
He that hath naught on earth but one poor daughter,
May take this ecstasy of care to keep her.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: And yet 'tis safe: they mean not to use force,
But fawning coming. I shall easily know
By his next question, if he think me rich,
Whom see I? my good lord?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Stand up good father, I call thee not father for thy age,
But that I gladly wish to be thy son,
In honoured marriage with thy beauteous daughter.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: O, so, so, so, so, so, this is for gold,
Now it is sure, this is my daughter's neatness,
Makes them believe me rich. No, my good lord,
I'll tell you all; how my poor hapless daughter
Got that attire she wears from top to toe.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Why father, this is nothing.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O yes, good my lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Indeed it is not.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Nay sweet lord pardon me? do not dissemble,
Hear your poor beadsman speak; 'tis requisite
That I (So huge a beggar) make account
Of things that pass my calling: she was born
T'enjoy nothing underneath the son:
But that, if she had more than other beggars
She should be envied: I will tell you then
How she had all she wears, her warm shoes (God wot)
A kind maid gave her, seeing her go barefoot
In a cold frosty morning; God requite her;
Her homely stockings

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Father, I'll hear no more, thou movest too much
With thy too curious answer for thy daughter,
That doth deserve a thousand times as much,
I'll be thy son in law, and she shall wear
Th'attire of countesses.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: O good my lord,
Mock not the poor, remembers not your lordship,
That poverty is the precious gift of God.
As well as riches, tread upon me, rather
Than mock my poorness.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Rise I say:
When I mock poorness, than heavens make me poor.

sp.speaker: Nvn.
sp.l: See here's the count Ferneze, I will tell him
The hapless accident of his brave son,
That he may seek the sooner to redeem him,
God save your lordship.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: You are right welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Nuntius
sp.p: I would I brought such news as might deserve it.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What, bring you me ill news?

sp.speaker: Nuntius
sp.l: 'Tis ill my lord,
Yet such as usual chance of war affords,
And for which all men are prepared that use it,
And those that use it not, but in their friends,
Or in their children.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Ill news of my son?
My dear and only son, I'll lay my soul,
Ay me accursed, thought of his death doth wound me,
And the report of it will kill me quite.

sp.speaker: Nuntius
sp.p: 'Tis not so ill my lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: How then?

sp.speaker: Nuntius
sp.l: He's taken prisoner, and that's all.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: That's enough, enough,
I set my thoughts on love, on servile love,
Forget my virtuous wife, feel not the dangers,
The bands and wounds of mine own flesh and blood,
And therein am a mad man: therein plagued,
With the most just affliction under heaven.
Is Maximilian taken prisoner to?

sp.speaker: Nuntius
sp.p: My good my lord, he is returned with prisoners.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Is't possible, can Maximilian?
Return, and view my face without my son,
For whom he swore such care as for himself?

sp.speaker: Nuntius
sp.p: My lord no care can change the events of war.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: O! in what tempests do my fortune's sail,
Still wracked with winds more foul and contrary,
Than any Northern guest, or Southern flaw?
That ever yet enforced the sea to gape,
And swallow the poor merchants traffic up?
First in Vicenza, lost I my first son;
Next here in Milan my most dear loved lady:
And now my Paulo, prisoner to the French,
Which last being printed with my other griefs,
Doth make so huge a volume, that my breast
Cannot contain them. But this is my love ▪
I must make love to Rachel, heaven hath thrown,
This vengeance on me most deservedly:
Were it for naught but wronging of my steward.

sp.speaker: Nuntius
sp.l: My lord since only money may redress
The worst of this misfortune, be not grieved,
Prepare his ransom and your noble son
Shall greet your cheered eyes, with the more honour.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I will prepare his ransom: gracious heaven
Grant his imprisonment may be his worst,
Honoured and soldierlike imprisonment,
And that he be not manacled and made
A drudge to his proud foe. And here I vow,
Never to dream of seeme-les amorous toys,
Nor aim at other joy on earth,
But the fruition of my only son.

div.head: Scene 5.
div.stage: Enter Jaques with his gold and a scuttle full of horse-dung.

sp.speaker: Iaq,
sp.l: He's gone: I knew it; this is our hot lover,
I will believe them! I! they may come in
Like simple wooers, and be arrant thieves,
And I not know them! 'tis not to be told,
What servile villainies, men will do for gold,
Oh it began to have a huge strong smell,
Which lying so long together in a place;
I'll give it vent, it shall ha' shift enough,
And if the devil, that envies all goodness,
Have told them of my gold, and where I kept it,
I'll set his burning nose once more a work,
To smell where I removed it, here it is:
I'll hide and cover it with this horse-dung:
Who will suppose that such a precious nest
Is crowned with such a dunghill excrement?
In my dear life, sleep sweetly my dear child.
"Scarce lawfully begotten, but yet gotten,
" and that's enough. Rot all hands that come near thee
Except mine own. Burn out all eyes that see thee,
Except mine own. All thoughts of thee be poison
To their enamoured hearts, except mine own,
I'll take no leave, sweet prince great emperor,
But see thee every minute, King of Kings,
I'll not be rude to thee, and turn my back,
In going from thee, but go backward out:
With my face towards thee, with humble courtesies,
None is within. None overlooks my wall.
To have gold, and to have it safe, is all.

div.head: Scene 1.
div.stage: Enter Maximilian, with soldiers Chamount, Camilla, Ferneze, Pacue.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Lord Chamount and your valiant friend there, I cannot say welcome to Milan: your thoughts and that word are not musical, but I can say you are come to Milan.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Mort diew.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Gar soon.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Gentlemen (I would call an emperor so) you are now my prisoners, I am sorry, marry this, spit in the face of your fortunes, for your usage shall be honourable.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: We know it signior Maximilian,
The fame of all your actions sounds naught else,
But perfect honour from her swelling cheeks.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: It shall do so still I assure you, and I will give you reason, there is in this last action (You know) a noble gentleman of our party, and a right valiant; semblably prisoner to your general, as your honoured self's to me, for whose safety, this tongue hath given warrant to his honourable father, the count Ferneze. You conceive me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I signior.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Well? than I must tell you your ransoms be to redeem him, what think you? your answer.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Marry with my lords leave here I say signior,
This free and ample offer you have made,
Agrees well with your honour, but not ours:
For I think not but Chamount is as well born
As is Ferneze, then if I mistake not,
He scorns to have his worth so underprised,
That it should need an adjunct, in exchange,
Of any equal fortune, noble signior?
I am a soldier, and I love Chamount,
Ere I would bruise his estimation,
With the least ruin of mine own respect,
In this vild kind, these legs should rot with irons,
This body pine in prison, till the flesh
Dropped from my bones in flakes, like withered leaves,
In heart of autumn, from a stubborn oak.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: Monsieur Gasper (I take it so is your name) misprise me not, I will trample on the heart, on the soul of him that shall say, I will wrong you: what I purpose, you cannot now know; but you shall know, and doubt not to your contentment. Lord Chamount, I will leave you, whilst I go in and present myself to the honourable count, till my regression so please you, your noble feet may measure this private, pleasant and most princely walk, soldiers regard them and respect them.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: O ver bon: excellenta gull, he tak'a my lord Chamount for monsieur Gaspra, and monsieur Gaspra for my lord Chamont, o dis be brave for make a me laugh'a, ha, ha, ha, o my heart tickla.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I but your lordship knows not what hard fate
Might have pursued us, therefore howsoe'er
The changing of our names was necessary
And we must now be careful to maintain
This error strongly, which our own device,
Hath thrust into their ignorant conceits,
For should we (On the taste of this good fortune)
Appear ourselves, 'twould both create in them
A kind of jealousy, and perchance invert
Those honourable courses they intend.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: True my dear Gasper: but this hang by here,
Will (At one time or other) on my soul
Discover us: a secret in his mouth
Is like a wild bird put into a cage,
Whose door no sooner opens, but 'tis out.
But sirrah, if I may but know
Thou utterst it

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Vtteria? vat monsieur?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: That he is Gasper, and I true Chamont.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: O pardon moy, fore my tongue shall put out de secreta,
Shall breed de cankra in my mouth.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Speak not so loud Pacue.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Foe, you shall not hear fool, for all your long ear, regard monsieur: you be de Chamont, Chamont be Gaspra.

div.stage: Enter count Ferveze, Maximilian, Francesco, Aurelia, Phoenixella, Finio.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Peace, here comes Maximilian.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: O belike that's the count Ferneze, that old man.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Are those his daughters, trow?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I sure, I think they are.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Fore God the taller is a gallant lady.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: So are they both believe me.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: True my honourable lord, that Chamont was the father of this man.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: O that may be, for when I lost my son,
This was but young it seems.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Faith had Camillo lived,
He had been much about his years, my lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: He had indeed, well, speak no more of him.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Signior perceive you the error? 'twas no good office in us to stretch the remembrance of so dear a loss. Count Ferneze, let summer sit in your eye, look cheerfully sweet count, will you do me the honour to confine this noble spirit within the circle of your arms?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Honoured Chamont reach me your valiant hand,
I could have wished some happier accident
Had made the way unto this mutual knowledge,
Which either of us now must take of other,
But sure it is the pleasure of our fates,
That we should thus be wracked on fortune's wheel,
Let us prepare with steeled patience
To tread on torment, and with minds confirmed
Welcome the worst of envy.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Noble lord, 'tis thus. I have here (In mine honour) set this gentleman free, without ransom, he is now himself, his valour hath deserved it, in the eye of my judgement. Monsieur Gasper you are dear to me: fortuna non mutuat genus. But to the main, if it may square with your lordship's liking, and his love, I could desire that he were now instantly employed to your noble general in the exchange of Ferneze for yourself, it is the business that requires the tender hand of a friend.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Ay, and it would be with more speed effected,
If he would undertake it.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: True my lord. Monsieur Gasper, how stand you affected to this motion?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: My duty must attend his lordship's will.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: What says the lord Chamont?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: My will doth then approve what these have urged.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Why there is good harmony, good music in these monsieur Gasper, you shall protract no time, only I will give you a bowl of rich wine to the health of your general, another to the success of your journey, and a third to the love of my sword. Pass.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Aurelia and Phoenixella.

sp.speaker: Anre.
sp.l: Why how now sister in a motley muse?
Go to, there's somewhat in the wind, I see.
Faith this brown study suits not with your black,
Your habit and your thoughts are of two colours.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: Good faith methinks that this young lord Chamont favours my mother, sister, does he not?

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: A motherly conceit, o blind excuse,
Blinder than love himself. Well sister, well.
Cupid hath ta'en his stand in both your eyes, the case is altered.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: And what of that?

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Nay nothing but a saint.
Another Bridget, one that for a face
Would put down Vesta, in whose looks doth swim,
The very sweetest cream of modesty.
You to turn tippet? fie, fie, will you give
A packing penny to virginity.
I thought you'd dwell so long in cypress I'll,
You'd worship madam Venus at the length;
But come, the strongest fall, and why not you?
Nay, do not frown.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: Go. go, you fool. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Well I may jest, or so: but Cupid knows
My taking is as bad, or worse than hers.
O monsieur Gasper? if thou beest a man,
Be not afraid to court me, do but speak,
Challenge thy right and wear it: for I swear
Till thou arrivedst, ne'er came affection here.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.l: Come on my sweet finical Pacue, the very prime
Of pages, here's an excellent place for us to practise in,
Nobody fees us here, come let's to it.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Contenta: reguarde, vou le preimer.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Sirrah Finio?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Mort deiu le peasant.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Didst thou see Valentine?

sp.speaker: Finio.
sp.p: Valentine? no.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Fini.
sp.p: No. Sirrah onion, whither goest?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: O I am vexed, he that would trust any of these lying travellers.

sp.speaker: Finio.
sp.p: I prithee stay good onion.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Monsieur onion, vene ca, come hidera, je vou prey. By gar me ha see two, tree, four hundred tousand of your Cousan hang. Lend me your hand, shall pray for know you bettra.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: I thank you good signior parla vou? O that I were in another world, in the ingies, or somewhere , that I might have room to laugh.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: A we fort boon: stand? you be dear now, me come, boon iour monsieur.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Good morrow good signior.

sp.speaker: Pac
sp.p: By gar, be much glad for see you.

sp.speaker: Fin
sp.p: I return you most kind thanks sir.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: How? how? 'sblood this is rare?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Nay, shall make you say rare by and by, regard monsieur Finio,

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Signior Pache.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Dieu vou guard monsieur.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: God save you sweet signior

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Monsieur Onion ? is not fort boon.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Beane? quoth he, would I were in debt of a pottle of beans I could do as much.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Welcome signior, what's next?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: O here, void de grand admiration, as should meet perchance monsieur Finio,

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Monsieur Pacue

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Jesu? by gar who think we shall meet here?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: By this hand I am not a little proud of it, sir

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: This trick is only for thee the chamber, it cannot be cleanly done abroad,

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Well what say you for dis den? Monsieur:

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Nay pray, sir.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Par ma foy vou bein encounters?

sp.speaker: Fin
sp.p: What do you mean sir, let your glove alone.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Comen, se portae la sante.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Faith exceeding well sir.

sp.speaker: Pac,
sp.p: Trot, be much joy for heir.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: And how is't with you sweet signior Pache.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Fat comme vou voyer.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Young gentlemen? spirits of blood, if ever you'll taste of a sweet piece of mutton, do onion a good turn now.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Que que, parla monsieur, what is't.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Faith teach me one of these tricks.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: O me shall do presently, stand you dear, you signior dear, myself is here: so fort bein, now I parley to monsieur onion, onion pratla to you, you speak-a to me, so, and as you parley change the bonnet, monsieur onion.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Mounseiur Finio.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Mounseur Pacue.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Pray be covera.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Nay I beseech you sir.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: What do you mean.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Pardon moy, shall be so,

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: O God sir.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Not I in good faith sir.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: By gar you must.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: It shall be yours.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Nay then you wrong me,

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Well and ever I come to be great.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: You be big enough for de onion already,

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: I mean a great man.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Then thou'dst be a monster.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Well God knows not what fortune may do, command me, use me from the soul to the crown, and the crown to the soul: meaning not only from the crown of the head, and the sole of the foot, but also the foot of the mind and the crowns of the purse, I cannot stay now young gentlemen but — time was, time is, and time shall be.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Sweet Jasper I am sorry we must part,
But strong necessity enforceth it.
Let not the time seem long unto my friend,
Till my return for by our love I swear
(The sacred sphere wherein our souls are knit)
I will endeavour to effect this business
With all industrious care and happy speed.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My lord these circumstances would come well,
To one less capable of your desert
Than I: in whom your merit is confirmed
With such authentical and grounded proves.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Well I will use no more. Gasper adieu.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Farewell my honoured lord.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Commend me to the lady, my good Gasper.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I had remembered that had not you urged it.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Once more adieu sweet Gasper.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: My good lord.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Thy virtues are more precious than thy name,
Kind gentleman I would not sell thy love,
For all the earthly objects that mine eyes,
Have ever tasted, sure thou art nobly born,
However fortune hath obscured thy birth:
For native honour sparkles in thine eyes,
How may I bless the time wherein Chamont
My honoured father did surprise Vicenza,
Where this my friend (Known by no name) was found,
Being then a child and scarce of power to speak,
To whom my father gave this name of Gasper,
And as his own respected him to death,
Since when we two have shared our mutual fortunes,
With equal spirits, and but death's rude hand,
No violence shall dissolve this sacred band.

div.stage: Enter Juniper in his shop singing: to him onion.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Fellow juniper, no more of thy songs and sonnets, sweet juniper, no more of thy hymns and madrigals, thou singest, but I sigh.

sp.speaker: Iuni
sp.p: What's the matter Peter ha? what in an academy still, still in sable, and costly black array? ha?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Prithee rise mount, mount sweet juniper, for I go down the wind, and yet I puff: for I am vexed.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p:
Ha bully? vexed? what intoxicate? is thy brain in a
quintessence? an idea? A metamorphosis? an apology? ha rogue? come this love feeds upon thee, I see by thy cheeks, and drinks healths of vermilion, tears I see by thine eyes.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: I confess Cupid's carouse, he plays super negulum with my liquor of life

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Tut, thou art a goose to be Cupid's gull, go to, no more of this contemplations, and calculations, mourn not, for Rachel's thine own

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: For that let the higher powers work: but sweet juniper, I am not sad for her, and yet for her in a second person, or if not so yet in a third.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: How second person? away, away, in the crotchets already longitude and latitude? what second? what person? ha?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Juniper, I'll bewray myself before thee, for thy company is sweet unto me, but I must entreat thy helping hand in the case.

sp.speaker: Juni.
