sp.p: Tut? no more of this surquedry; I am thine own? ad ungem upsy freeze: pell-mell , come, what case? what case?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: For the case it may be any man's case, as well as mine, Rachel I mean, but I'll meddle with her anon, in the mean time, Valentine is the man hath wronged me.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: How my ingle wrong thee, is't possible?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Your ingle, hang him infidel, well and if I be not revenged one him let Peter Onion (By the infernal gods) be turned to all eke or a scallion, I spoke to him for a ditty for this hankercher.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Why, has he not done it?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Done it, not a verse by this hand.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: O in dichus illis, oh preposterous, well come be blithe, the best judge of the is sometimes dull, fellow onion pardon mine juggle: he is a man, has imperfections and declinations, as other men have, his mass sometimes cannot carnet nor prognosticate and come of, as it should, no matter, I'll hammer our a paraphrase for thee myself.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p:
No sweet juniper, no danger 〈◊〉 breed delay, love
makes me choleric I can bear no longer.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Not bear? what my mad meridian slave? not be are? what?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Cupid's burden: 'tis too heavy, too tolerable, and as for the handkerchief and the posy: I will not trouble thee: but if thou wilt go with me into her father's backside, old Jaques backside, and speak for me to Rachel, I will not being ratitude, the old man is abroad and all.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Art thou sure on't.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: As sure as an obligation.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Let's away then, come we spend time in a vain circumference, trade ●cashire thee till tomorrow, fellow onion for thy sake I finish this workaday.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: God a mercy, and for thy sake I'll at any time make a holiday.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Nay I prithee Rachel, I come to comfort thee, be not so sad.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: O signior Angelo,
No comfort but his presence can remove,
This sadness from my heart.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Nay then you're fond,
And want that strength of judgement and election,
That should be attendent on your years and form,
Will you, because your lord is taken prisoner,
Blubber and weep and keep a peevish stir,
As though you would turn turtle with the news,
Come, come, be wise. 'sblood say your lord should die:
And you go mar your face as you begin,
What would you do trow? who would care for you;
But this it is, when nature will bestow
Her gifts on such as know not how to use them,
You shall have some that had they but one quarter
Of your fair beauty? they would make it show
A little otherwise than you do this,
Or they would see the painter twice an hour,
And I commend them I, that can use art,
With such judicial practice.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: You talk idly,
If this be your best comfort keep it still,
My senses cannot feed on such sour cates.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: And why sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Nay leave good signior.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Come I have sweeter viands yet in store.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: I in any case mistress Rachel.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Rachel?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: God's pity signior Angelo, I hear my father, away for god's sake.

sp.speaker: Ang:
sp.p: 'Sblood, I am betwixt, I think, this is twice now, I have been served thus.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Pray God he meet him not.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: O brave? she's yonder, oh terrible she's gone.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Yea? so nimble in your dilemmas, and your hyperboles hay my love? O my love, at the first sight: by the mass.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: O how she scudded, oh sweet scud, how she tripped, oh delicate trip and go.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Come thou art enamoured with the influence of her profundity, but sirrah hark a little.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: O rare, what? what? passing i'faith, what is't? what is't?

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: What wilt thou say now, if Rachel stand now, and play hity-tity through the key hole, to behold the equipage of thy person:

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: O sweet equipage, try good juniper, tickle her, talk, talk, o? Rare

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Mistress Rachel (Watch then if her father come) Rachel? Madona? Rachel? no.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Say I am here, onion or Peter or so.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: No, I'll knock, we'll not stand upon horizons, and tricks, but fall roundly to the matter.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Well said sweet juniper: orisons? hang hem? knock, knock.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Who's there? father.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Father no? and yet a father, if you please to be a mother.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Well said juniper, to her again, a smack or two more of the mother

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Do you here? sweet soul, sweet Radamant? sweet Mathavell one word Melpomene? are you at leisure.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: At leisure? what to do?

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: To do what, to do nothing, but to be liable to the ecstasy of true love's exigent, or so, you smell my meaning.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Smell, filthy, fellow juniper filthy? smell? O most odious.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: How filthy.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Filthy, by this finger? smell? smell a rat, smell a pudding, away these tricks are for trulls, a plain wench loves plain dealing, I'll upon myself, smell to march pain wench.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: With all my heart, I'll be legitimate and silent as an apple-squire, I'll see nothing, and say nothing.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Sweet heart, sweet heart?

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: And bag pudding, ha, ha, ha?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: What Rachel my girl what Rachel;

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: God's lid ▪

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: What Rachel,

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Here I am

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: What rakehell calls Rachel: oh treason to my love.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: It's her father on my life, how shall we entrench and edify ourselves from him?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: O coney-catching ▪ Cupid.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: How in my back side? where? what come they for?
sp.stage: Onion gets up into a tree.
sp.l: Where are they? Rachel? thieves, thieves?
Stay villain slave: Rachel? untie my dog.
Nay thief thou canst not scape.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: I pray you sir.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: A pitiful onion, that thou hadst a rope.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Why Rachel: when I say: let loose my dog? garlic my mastiff, let him lose I say.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: For god's sake hear me speak, keep up your cur.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: I fear not garlic, he'll not bite onion his kinsman pray God he come out, and then they'll not smell me.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Well then deliver, come deliver slave?

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: What should I deliver?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O thou wouldst have me tell thee? wouldst thou show me thy hands, what hast thou in thy hands?

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Here be my hands.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Stay are not thy fingers ends begrimed with dirt, no thou hast wiped them.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Wiped them?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I thou villain? thou art a subtle knave, put off thy shows, come I will see them, give me a knife here Rachel, I'll rip the soles.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: No matter he's a cobbler, he can mend them.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: What are you mad? are you detestable, would you make an anatomy of me, think you I am not true orthography?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Orthography, anatomy?

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: For god's sake be not so inviolable, I am no ambuscado, what predicament call you this, why do you intimate so much.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I can feel nothing.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: By'r lady but onion feels something.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Soft sir, you are not yet gone, shake your legs, come, and your arms, be brief, stay let me see these drums, these kilderkins, these bombard slops, what is it crams hem so.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Nothing but hair.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: That's true, I had almost forgotten this rug, this hedgehogs nest, this hay mow, this bears skin, this heath, this firsbush.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p:
O let me go, you tear my hair, you resolve my
brains and understanding.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Heart, thou art somewhat eased? half of my fear
Hath ta'en his leave of my, the other half
Still keeps possession in despite of hope,
Until these amorous eyes, court my fair gold:
Dear I come to thee: friend, why art not gone?
Avoid my soul's vexation, Sathan hence?
Why dost thou stare on me, why dost thou stay?
Why poorest thou on the ground with thievish eyes?
What seest thou there, thou cur? what gapest thou at?
Hence from my house, Rachel, send garlic forth.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: I am gone sir, I am gone, for god's sake stay.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Pack, and thank God thou scapest so well away.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: If I scape this tree, destinies, I defy you.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: I cannot see by any characters
Writ on this earth, that any felon foot
Hath ta'en acquaintance of this hallowed ground.
None sees me: knees do homage to your lord.
'Tis safe, 'tis safe, it lies and sleeps so soundly,
'Twould do one good to look on't. If this bliss
Be given to any man that hath much gold,
Justly to say 'tis safe, I say 'tis safe.
O what a heavenly round these two words dance
Within me and without me: first I think hem,
And then I speak hem, than I watch their sound,
And drink it greedily with both mine ears,
Then think, then speak, then drink their sound again,
And racket round about this body's court.
These two sweet words: 'tis safe: stay I will feed
My other senses, o how sweet it smells

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: I mar'le he smells not onion, being so near it.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Down to thy grave again, thou beauteous ghost,
Angels men say, are spirits: spirits be
Invisible, bright angels are you so?
Be you invisible to every eye.
Save only these: sleep, I'll not break your rest,
Though you break mine: dear saints adieu, adieu:
My feet part from you, but my soul dwells with you.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.l: Is he gone? O fortune my friend, and not fortune my foe,
I come down to embrace thee, and kiss thy great toe.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: Fellow onion? Peter.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Fellow juniper. What's the old panurgo gone? departed, cosmografied, ha?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: O ay, and hark sirrah. Shall I tell him? no.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: Nay, be brief and declare, stand not upon conundrums now, thou knowest what contagious speeches I have suffered for thy sake and he should come again and invent me here.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.l: He says true, it was for my sake, I will tell him.
Sirrah juniper? and yet I will not.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: What sayest thou sweet onion?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: And thou hadst smelled the scent of me when I was in the tree, thou wouldst not have said so: but sirrah, the case is altered with me, my heart has given love a box of the ear, made him kick up the heels i'faith.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: Sayest thou me so, wad Greek? how haps it? how chances it.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: I cannot hold it, juniper, have an eye, look, have an eye to the door, the old proverb's true, I see: gold is but muck. Nay gods so juniper to the door, an eye to the main chance, here you slave, have an eye.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: O inexorable! O infallible! O intricate divine, and superficial fortune.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Nay, it will be sufficient anon, here, look here.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: O insolent good luck! How didst thou produce th'intelligence of the gold minerals.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.l: I'll tell you that anon, here, make shift, convey, cram.
I'll teach you how you shall call for garlic again i'faith.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: 'Sblood what shall we do with all this? we shall ne'er bring it to a consumption.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Consumption? why we'll be most sumptuously attired, man.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: By this gold, I will have three or four most stigmatical suits presently.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: I'll go in my foot-cloth, I'll turn gentleman.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: So will I.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: But what badge shall we give, what cullison?

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: As for that let's use the infidelity and commiseration of some harlot of arms, he shall give us a gudgeon.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: A gudgeon? A scutcheon thou wouldst say, man.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: A scutcheon or a gudgeon, all is one.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Well, our arms be good enough, let's look to our legs.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: Content, we'll be jogging.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Rachel? we retire: garlic God boy ye.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: Farewell sweet Jaques.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Farewell sweet Rachel, sweet dog adieu.

div.stage: Enter Maximilian, count Ferneze, Aurelia, Phoenixella, Pache.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Nay but sweet count.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Away, I'll hear no more,
Never was man so palpably abused,
My son so basely marted; and myself
Am made the subject of your mirth and scorn.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Count Ferneze you tread too hard upon my patience,
Do not persist I advise your lordship.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I will persist, and unto thee I speak.
Thou., Maximilian thou hast injured me.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Before the lord:

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Sweet signior.

sp.speaker: Phoe
sp.p: O my father.

sp.speaker: Mux.
sp.p: Lady let your father thank your beauty.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: By gar me shall be hang for tella dis same,
Metella mademoiselle , she tell her sadera.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: The true Chamount set free, and one left here
Of no descent, clad barely in his name.
Sirrah boy come hither, and be sure, you speak the simple truth:

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: O pardon moy monsieur,

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: Come leave your pardons, and directly say.
What villain is the same that hath usurped,
The honoured name and person of Chamount:

sp.speaker: Pac
sp.p: O monsieur, no point villain, brave chevalier, monsieur Gasper.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Monsieur Gasper, on what occasion did they change their names, what was their policy, or their pretext.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Me canno tell, par ma foy monsieur.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: My honourable lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Tut tut, be silent.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Silent? Count Ferneze, I tell thee if Amurath the great
Turk were here I would speak, and he should hear me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: So will not I.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: By my father's hand, but thou shalt count, I say till this instant, I was never touched in my reputation: hear me you shall know that you have wronged me, and I will make you acknowledge it, if I cannot my sword shall.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: By heaven I will not, I will stop mine ears,
My senses loathe the saviour of thy breath.
'Tis poison to me, I say I will not hear.
What shall I know, 'tis you have injured me,
What will you make? make me acknowledge it.
Fetch forth that Gasper, that lewd counterfeit.
I'll make him to your face approve your wrongs.
Come on false substance, shadow to Chamont:
Had you none else to work upon but me,
Was I your fittest project? well confess,
What you intended by this secret plot.
And by whose policy it was contrived,
Speak truth, and be entreated courteously,
But double with me, and resolve to prove
The extremest rigor that I can inflict.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My honoured lord, hear me with patience,
Nor hope of favour, not the fear of torment,
Shall sway my tongue, from uttering of a truth.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Tis well, proceed then.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: The morn before this battle did begin,
Wherein my lord Chamount and I were ta'en,
We vowed one mutual fortune, good or bad,
That day should be embraced of us both,
And urging that might worst succeed our vow,
We there concluded to exchange our names.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Then Maximilian took you for Chamount.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: True noble lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: 'Tis false, ignoble wretch,
'Twas but a complot to betray my son.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Count, thou liest in thy bosom, count ▪

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Lie?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Nay I beseech you honoured gentlemen,
Let not the untimely ruin of your love,
Follow these sleight occurrents; be assured
Chamount's return will heal these wounds again,
And break the points of your too piercing thoughts.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Return? I when? when will Chamount return?
He'll come to fetch you, will he? I 'tis like,
You'd have methink so, that's your policy.
No, no, young gallant, your device is stale,
You cannot feed me with so vain a hope.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My lord, I feed you not with a vain hope,
I know assuredly he will return,
And bring your noble son along with him.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Ay, I dare pawn my soul he will return.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: O impudent derision? open scorn?
Intolerable wrong? is't not enough?
That you have played upon me all this while;
But still to mock me, still to jest at me?
Fellows, away with him, thou ill-bred slave,
That sets no difference twixt a noble spirit,
And thy own slavish humour, do not think
But I'll take worthy vengeance on thee, wretch?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Alas, these threats are idle, like the wind,
And breed no terror in a guiltless mind.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Nay, thou shalt want no torture, so resolve, bring him away.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Welcome the worst, I suffer for a friend,
Your tortures will, my love shall never end.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Alas poor gentleman, my father's rage
Is too extreme, too stern and violent
Oh that I knew with all my strongest powers,
How to remove it from thy patient breast,
But that I cannot, yet my willing heart,
Shall minister in spite of tyranny
To thy misfortune, something there is in him,
That doth enforce this strange affection,
With more than common rapture in my breast:
For being but Gasper, he is still as dear
To me, as when he did Chamount appear.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.p: But in good sadness signior, do you think Chamount will return?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Do I see your face, lady?

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.p: I sure, if love have not blinded you.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: That is a question, but I will assure you no, I can see, and yet love is in mine eye: well, the count your father simply hath dishonoured me: and this steel shall engrave it on his burgonet.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.p: Nay, sweet signior.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Lady, I do prefer my reputation to my life,
But you shall rule me, come let's march.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: I'll follow signior, o sweet Queen of love!
Sovereign of all my thoughts, and thou fair fortune,
Who (More to honour my affections)
Hast thus translated Gasper to Chamount.
Let both your flames now burn in one bright spear;
And give true light to my aspiring hopes,
Hasten Chamount's return, let him affect me,
Though father, friends, and all the world reject me.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Sigh for a woman, would I fouled mine arms,
Rave in my sleep, talk idly being awake,
Pine and look pale, make love-walks in the night,
To steal cold comfort from a day-star's eyes.
Kit, thou art a fool, wilt thou be wise? then lad
Renounce this boy-god's nice idolatry,
Stand not on compliment, and wooing tricks,
Thou lovest old Jaques daughter, dost thou?

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Love her?

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Come, come, I know't, be ruled and she's thine own,
Thou'lt say her father Jaques, the old beggar,
Hath pawned his word to thee, that none but thou,
Shalt be his son in law.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: He has.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: He has? wilt thou believe him, and be made a cook,
To wait on such an antique weather cock;
Why he is more inconstant than the sea,
His thoughts, chameleonlike, change every minute:
No kit, work soundly, steal the wench away,
Wed her, and bed her, and when that is done,
Then say to Jaques, shall I be your son?
But come to our device, where is this gold?

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Here signior Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Bestow it, bid thy hands shed golden drops,
Let these bald French crowns be uncovered,
In open sight, to do obeisance
To Jaques staring eyes when he steps forth,
The needy beggar will be glad of gold.
So, now keep thou aloof, and as he treads
This guilded path, stretch out his ambling hopes,
With scattering more and more, and as thou goest, cry Jaques, Jaques

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Tust, let me alone.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: First I'll play the ghost, I'll call him out, Kit keep aloof.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: But signior Angelo. Where will yourself and Rachel stay for me, after the jest is ended?

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Mass, that's true, at the old priory behind s. Foyes.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Agreed, no better place, I'll meet you there.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Do good fool, do, but I'll not meet you there.
Now to this gear, Jaques, Jaques, what Jaques?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Who calls? who's there?

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Jaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Who calls?

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Steward, he comes, he comes Jaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: What voice is this? nobody here, was I not called? I was.
And one cried Jaques with a hollow voice,
I was deceived, no I was not deceived,
See see, it was an angel called me forth,
Gold, gold, man ▪ making gold, another star,
Drop they from heaven, no, no, my house I hope
Is haunted with a fairy. My dear lar,
My household God, my fairy on my knees.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Jaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: My lar doth call me, o sweet voice.
Musical as the spheres, see, see, more gold.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Jaques.
What Rachel, Rachel, lock my door, look to my house.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Jaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Shut fast my door, a golden crown, Jaques shall be a King.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: To a fool's paradise that path will bring
Thee and thy household Lar.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: What means my father, I wonder what strange humour.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Come sweet soul, leave wondering, start not, 'twas I laid this plot to get thy father forth.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: O Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: O me no oo's, but hear, my lord your love,
Paulo Ferneze is returned from war,
Lingers at Pont Valeria, and from thence
By post at midnight last, I was conjured
To man you thither, stand not on replies,
A horse is saddled for you, will you go,
And I am for you, if you will stay, why so.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: O Angelo, each minute is a day till my Ferneze come, come we'll away sir.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Sweet soul I guess thy meaning by thy looks,
At pont Valerio thou thy love shalt see,
But not Ferneze, steward fare you well.
You wait for Rachel to, when can you tell?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: O in what golden circle have I danced?
Milan these odorous and enfloured fields
Are none of thine, no here's Elysium,
Here blessed ghosts do walk, this is the court
And glorious palace where the god of gold
Shines like the son, of sparkling majesty;
Oh fair feathered, my red-breasted birds,
Come fly with me, I'll bring you to a quire,
Whose consort being sweetened with your sound:
The music will be fuller, and each hour
These ears shall banquet with your harmony o, o, o,

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: At the old priory, behind saint Foyes,
That was the place of our appointment sure:
I hope he will not make me lose my gold,
And mock me to, perhaps they are within: I'll knock.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O God, the case is altered.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Rachel?

sp.speaker: Angelo?
sp.p: Signior Angelo?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Angels? I where? mine angels? where's my gold?
Why Rachel? O thou thievish cannibal,
Thou eatest my flesh in stealing of my gold.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: What gold?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: What gold? Rachel call help, come forth,
I'll rip thine entrails, but I'll have my gold:
Rachel why comes thou not? I am undone,
Ay me she speaks not, thou hast slain my child.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: What is the man possessed trow? this is strange,
Rachel I see is gone with Angelo:
Well I'll once again unto the priory,
And see if I can meet them.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: 'Tis too true,
Thou'st made away my child, how haste my gold:
Oh what hyena called me out of doors,
The thief is gone: my gold's gone, Rachel's gone,
All's gone? save I that spend my cries in vain,
But I'll hence too, and die or end this pain.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.l: 'Swounds, let me go, hay catso, catch him alive,
I call, I call, boy, I come, I come sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Page hold my rapier, while I hold my friend here.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: O here's a sweet metamorphosis, a couple of buzzards turned to a pair of peacocks.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Signior onion, lend me thy boy to unhang my rapier. On signior juniper for once or so, but troth is, you must inveigle, as I have done, my lords page here a poor follower of mine.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Hei ho, your page then sha'not be super intendent upon me? he shall not be addicted? he shall not be incident? he shall not be incident? he shall not be incident, shall he?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.l: O sweet signior juniper.
Juni 'sblood stand away princocks? do not aggravate my joy.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Nay good master. Onion.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Nay and he have the heart to draw my blood, let him come.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: I'll slice you onion, I'll slice you?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: I'll cleave you juniper.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Why hold, hold, hough? what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p:
Let him come ingle, stand by boy, his alabaster blade
cannot fear me.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Why hear you sweet signior, let not there be any contention, between my master and you, about me, if you want a page sir, I can help you to a proper stripling.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Canst thou? what parentage? what ancestry? what genealogy is he?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: A French boy sir.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Has he his French linguist? has he?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Ay, sir.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Then transport him: here's a crusado for thee.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: You will not, imbecile my servant with your benevolence will you, hold boy their's a portmanteau for thee.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Lord sir.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Do take it boy, it's three pounds ten shill a portmanteau.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: I thank your lordship.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.l: Sirrah ningle: thou art a traveller, and I honour thee.
I prithee discourse? cherish thy muse? discourse?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Of what sir?

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Of what thou wilt. 'sblood? hang sorrow?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Prithee Valentine assoil me one thing.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: 'Tis pity to soil you sir, your new apparel.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Mass thou sayest true, apparel makes a man forget himself.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: Begin, find your tongue ningle.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Now will gull these ganders rarely:
Gentlemen having in my peregrination through Mesopotamia.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Speak legibly, this game's gone, without the great mercy of God,
Here's a fine tragedy indeed. There's a keisars royal.
By god's lid, nor King nor keisar shall?

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.p: Where? where? Finio, where be they.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: Go to, I'll be with you anon.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: O here's the page signior juniper:

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: What say monsieur onion, boy.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: What say you sir.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Tread out boy.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Take up, you mean sir.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: Tread out I say, so, I thank you, is this the boy.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Aue monsieur.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Who gave you that name.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Give me de name, vat name:

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: He thought your name had been, we young gentlemen, you must do more than his legs can do for him, bear with him sir.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Sirrah give me instance of your carriage? you'll serve my turn, will you?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: What? turn upon the toe.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: O signior no.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Page will you follow me, I'll give you good exhibition.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: By gar, shall not alone follow you, but shall lead you to.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Plaguy boy, he soothes his humour? these French villains ha' pocky wits.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Here? disarm me? take my cemetery.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: O rare, this would be a rare man, and he had a little travel, Balthasar, Martino, put off your shoes, and bid him cobble them.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Friends, friends, but pardon me for fellows, no more in occupation, no more in corporation, 'tis so pardon me, the case is altered, this is law, but I'll stand to nothing.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Fat so me tinke.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Well then God save the Duke's majesty, is this any harm now? speak, is this any harm now.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: No nor good neither, 'sblood?

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: Do you laugh at me? do you laugh at me? do you laugh at me?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Ay sir, we do.

sp.speaker: Junip.
sp.p: You do indeed?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Juni.
sp.p: 'Tis sufficient, page carry my purse, dog me?

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: Gentlemen leave him not, you see in what case he is, he is not in adversity, his purse is full of money, leave him not?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Nay gentle Rachel?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Away? forbear? ungentle Angelo,
Touch not my body, with those impious hands,
That like hot irons sear my trembling heart,
And 〈◊〉 it hiss, at your disloyalty.
Wa● 〈◊〉 your drift? to use Ferneze's name?
Was he your fittest stale, o wild dishonour!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Stay noble sir ▪

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: 'Sblood how like a puppet do you talk now?
Dishonour? what dishonour? come, come, fool,
Nay then I see you're peevish, s'heart dishonour?
To have you to a priest and marry you,
And put you in an honourable state.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: To marry me? O heaven, can it be?
That men should live with such unfeeling souls,
Without or touch or conscience of religion,
Or that their warping appetites should spoil
Those honoured forms, that the true seal of friendship
Had set upon their faces.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Do you hear? what needs all this? say, will you have me, or no?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: I'll have you gone, and leave me, if you would.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Leave you? I was accursed to bring you hither,
And make so fair an offer to a fool.
A pox upon you, why should you be coy,
What good thing have you in you to be proud of?
Are y'any other than a beggar's daughter?
Because you have beauty. O God's light a blast.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: You scornful baggage, I loved thee not so much, but now I hate thee.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Upon my knees, you heavenly powers, I thank you,
That thus have tamed his wild affections.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: This will not do, I must to her again,
Rachel, o that thou sawest my heart, or didst behold,
The place from whence that scalding sigh evented.
Rachel, by Jesu I love thee as my soul, Rachel, sweet Rachel.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: What again returned unto this violent passion.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Do but hear me, by heaven I love you Rachel.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Pray forbear, o that my lord Ferneze were but here.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: 'Sblood and he were, what would he do.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: This would he do base villain.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: My dear lord,

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Thou monster, even the soul of treachery!
O what dishonoured title of reproach,
May my tongue spit in thy deserved face?
Methinks my very presence should invert,
The steeled organs of those traitorous eyes,
To take into thy heart, and pierce it through:
Turnest thou them on the ground? wretch, dig a grave,
With their sharp points, to hide th'abhorred head;
Sweet love, thy wrongs have been too violent
Since my departure from thee, I perceive:
But now true comfort shall again appear,
And like an armed angel guard thee safe
From all th'assaults of covered villainy.
Come monsieur, let's go, and leave this wretch to his despair.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: My noble Ferneze.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: What canst thou speak to me, and not thy tongue,
Forced with the torment of thy guilty soul
Break that infected circle of thy mouth,
Like the rude clapper of a crazed bell.
Ay, that in thy bosom lodged my soul,
With all her train of secrets, thinking them
To be as safe, and richly entertained,
As in a prince's court, or tower of strength,
And thou to prove a traitor to my trust,
And basely to expose it, o this world!

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: My honourable lord.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: The very owl, whom other birds do stare and wonder at,
Shall hoot at thee, and snakes in every bush
Shall deaf thine ears with their —

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Nay good my lord, give end unto your passions.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: You shall see, I will redeem your lost opinion.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: My lord believe him.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Come, be satisfied, sweet lord you know our haste,
Let us to horse, the time for my engaged return is past;
Be friends again, take him along with you.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Come signior Angelo, hereafter prove more true.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Tut Maximillian, for your honoured self,
I am persuaded, but no words shall turn
The edge of purposed vengeance on that wretch,
Come, bring him forth to execution.
I'll hang him for my son, he shall not scape,
Had he an hundred lives: tell me vile slave,
Thinkest thou I love my son? is he my flesh?
Is he my blood, my life? and shall all these be tortured for thy
Sake, and not revenged? truss up the villain.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: My lord, there is no law to confirm this action.
'Tis dishonourable.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Dishonourable? Maximilian ?
It is dishonourable in Chamount, the day of his prefixt return is past, and he shall pay fort.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My lord, my lord,
Use your extremest vengeance, I'll be glad
To suffer ten times more, for such a friend.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O resolute and peremptory wretch!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My honoured lord, let us entreat a word.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I'll hear no more, I say he shall not live,
Myself will do it. Stay, what form is this
Stands betwixt him and me, and holds my hand.
What miracle is this? 'tis my own fancy,
Carves this impression in me, my soft nature,
That ever hath retained such foolish pity,
Of the most abject creatures misery,
That it abhors it, what a child am I
To have a child? Ay me, my son, my son.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: O my dear love, what is become of thee?
What unjust absence layest thou on my breast,
Like weights of lead, when swords are at my back,
That run me through with thy unkind flight,
My gentle disposition waxeth wild,
I shall run frantic, o my love, my love.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: My gold, my gold, my life, my soul, my heaven,
What is become of thee? see, I'll impart
My miserable loss to my good lord,
Let me have search my lord, my gold is gone.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: My son, Christophero, thinkst it possible,
I ever shall behold his face again.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: O father where's my love, were you so careless
To let an unthrift steal away your child.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: I know your lordship may find out my gold,
For god's sake pity me, justice, sweet lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Now they have young Chamount? Christophero?
Surely they never will restore my son.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Who would have thought you could have been so careless to lose your only daughter.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Who would think,
That looking to my gold with such hares eyes,
That ever open, I even when thy sleep,
I thus should lose my gold, my noble lord, what says your
Lordship?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O my son, my son.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: My dearest Rachel?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: My most honey gold.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Hear me Christophero.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Nay hear me Jaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Hear me most honoured lord.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: What rule is here?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O God that we should let Chamount escape.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: I and that Rachel, such a virtuous maid, should be thus stolen away.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: And that my gold, being so hid in earth, should be found out.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: O confusion of languages, and yet no tower of Babel!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ladies, beshrew me, if you come not fit to make a jangling consort, will you laugh to see three constant passions.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Stand by, I will urge them, sweet count, will you be comforted.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: It cannot be but he is handled the most cruelly,
That ever any noble prisoner was.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Steward, go cheer my lord:

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Well, if Rachel took her flight willingly?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Sirrah, speak you touching your daughter's flight?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O that I could so soon forget to know the thief again, that had my gold, my gold.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Is not this pure ▪

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: O thou base wretch, I'll drag thee through the streets.
sp.stage: Enter Balthasar, and whispers with him.
sp.l: And as a monster, make thee wondered at, how now.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Sweet gentleman? how too unworthily
Art thou thus tortured, brave Maximillian,
Pity the poor youth and appease my father,

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: How, my son returned? O Maximillian,
Francisco, daughters? bid him enter here.
Dost thou not mock me? O my dear Paulo welcome.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: My lord Chamount?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: My Gasper.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Rachel.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: My gold Rachel? my gold?

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: somebody bid the beggar cease his noise.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: O signior Angelo, would you deceive
Your honest friend, that simply trusted you?
Well Rachel: I am glad thou art here again.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: i'faith she is not for you steward.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I beseech you madam urge your father.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: I will anon? good Jaques be content.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Now God a mercy fortune, and sweet Venus,
Let Cupid do his part, and all is well.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: methinks my heart's in heaven with this comfort.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Is this the true Italian courtesy.
Ferneze were you tortured thus in France? by my soul's safety.

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.p: My most noble lord? I do beseech your lordship.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Honoured count, wrong not your age with flexure of a knee,
I do impute it to those cares and griefs,
That did torment you in your absent son.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: O worthy gentlemen, I am a shamed
That my extreme affection to my son,
Should give my honour so uncured a main,
But my first son, being in Vicenza lost.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: How in Vicenza? lost you a son there?
About what time my lord?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O the same night, wherein your noble father took the town.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: How long's that since my lord? can you remember.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Tis now well nigh upon the twentieth year.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: And how old was he then?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I cannot tell, between the years of three and sour, I take it.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Had he no special note in his attire,
Or otherwise, that you can call to mind.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: I cannot well remember his attire,
But I have often heard his mother say:
He had about his neck a tablet,
Given to him by the emperor Sigismund.
His godfather, with this inscription,
Under the figure of a silver globe: en minimo, mundus.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: How did you call your son my lord?

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Camillo lord Chamount.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Then no more my Gasper? but Camillo,
Take notice of your father, gentlemen:
Stand not amazed? here is a tablet,
With that inscription? found about his neck
That night, and in Vicenza by my father,
(Who being ignorant, what name he had)
Christened him Gasper, nor did I reveal,
This secret till this hour to any man.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O happy revelation? O blessed hour? O my Camillo.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: O strange my brother.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Maximilian? behold how the abundance of his joy drowns him in tears of gladness.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O my boy? forgive thy father's late austerity:

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: My lord? I delivered as much before, but your honour would not be persuaded, I will hereafter give more observance to my visions? I dreamt of this.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: I can be still no longer, my good lord,
Do a poor man some grace amongst all your joys.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Why what's the matter Jaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: I am robbed, I am undone my lord, robbed and undone:
A heap of thirty thousand golden crowns,
Stolen from me in one minute, and I fear:
By her confederacy, that calls me father,
But she's none of mine, therefore sweet lord:
Let her be tortured to confess the truth.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: More wonders yet.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: How Jaques is not Rachel than thy daughter.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: No, I disclaim in her, I spit at her,

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
